Due to high demand from the pro-life camp, I have come up with a modest proposal regarding abortion and pregnancy. First, lets examine the basic debate over abortion. The pro-choicers would say that a fetus is a part of a woman's body and a woman should be able to control that part of her body. They would also say that a fetus is not a conscious being. But in their infinite wisdom many pro-life people would respond to that by saying, "it has the potential to become a conscious being." 
 
 Based on this ingenius idea of potential, I will establish my proposal. Right now all people of both genders have the potential for life, or at least half of it each. Therefore, to be ethically correct, all people should have sex in all of their spare time. This would properly maximize the potential for life, and we know that if we do not utilize this potential to the maximum we are killing people, just as abortion kills people. 
 
 In order to enforce this modest proposal on those who will not be morally correct on their own, the pro-choicers, I have come up with a three part plan. First, all birth control methods will be outlawed. Second, the government should administer mandatory pregnancy tests to all women once a month to make sure that they are pregnant. If a woman is not pregnant at the time of the test then she has until the next test to become pregnant. If not she will be electrocuted. Or perhaps a more effective technique, a professional raping squad will be sent out to impregnate her. And third, all people who are sterile will be put in front of the shooting squad immediately because they are completely worthless. 
 
 Through this plan, we can crank out as many people as possible, completely overpopulate, destroy the environment, destroy all natural resources in under 5 years, and finally all die. Just consider this modest proposal.

Due to high demand from the pro-life camp, I have come up with a modest proposal regarding abortion and pregnancy. First, lets examine the basic debate over abortion. The pro-choicers would say that a fetus is a part of a woman's body and a woman should be able to control that part of her body. They would also say that a fetus is not a conscious being. But in their infinite wisdom many pro-life people would respond to that by saying, "it has the potential to become a conscious being." 

 
 A woman's rights over her body aren't absolute at all. When a woman who's OD'ed is brought to a hospital, they take steps to save her... they don't just say "She's a druggie, she's obviously sick of life, we'll respect her right to die". Even if she recovers, and lucidly announces the same intent, they will take steps to stop her. It is because it is un-natural. It is un-natural to kill another human or to harm another human. People do it, but we don't just accept it... we try and put these people into a place where they're not going to do it again.
 
 Further, if a woman smokes, her 'right to smoke' might impinge upon my right to be in a smoke free environment. Why is it that restaurants (at least in this country) now have to be smoke free? Why is my right greater than hers?
 
 
Based on this ingenius (sic) idea of potential, I will establish my proposal. Right now all people of both genders have the potential for life, or at least half of it each. Therefore, to be ethically correct, all people should have sex in all of their spare time. This would properly maximize the potential for life, and we know that if we do not utilize this potential to the maximum we are killing people, just as abortion kills people. 

 
 I don't fight for the rights of the foetus because I think it's 'potentially' human. I think it's 'actually' human.
 
 That people have the potential to create life, doesn't mean that they have to do it. I have the potential to kill you... should I do it, simply because I have the potential to do it?
 
 
In order to enforce this modest proposal on those who will not be morally correct on their own, the pro-choicers, I have come up with a three part plan. First, all birth control methods will be outlawed. Second, the government should administer mandatory pregnancy tests to all women once a month to make sure that they are pregnant. Or perhaps a more effective technique, a professional raping squad will be sent out to impregnate her. And third, all people who are sterile will be put in front of the shooting squad immediately because they are completely worthless.

 I do hope you're not serious. If you aren't then you've picked an odd topic to joke about.

A woman's rights over her body aren't absolute at all. When a woman who's OD'ed is brought to a hospital, they take steps to save her... they don't just say "She's a druggie, she's obviously sick of life, we'll respect her right to die". Even if she recovers, and lucidly announces the same intent, they will take steps to stop her. It is because it is un-natural. It is un-natural to kill another human or to harm another human. People do it, but we don't just accept it... we try and put these people into a place where they're not going to do it again.
 
 Further, if a woman smokes, her 'right to smoke' might impinge upon my right to be in a smoke free environment. Why is it that restaurants (at least in this country) now have to be smoke free? Why is my right greater than hers?
 
 I might point out that the woman in question has every right to go down and file a DNR and a living will, and then the medical responders would be required by law to adhere to it. If she went and OD'ed again, and was going to die, they would have to let her die... in effect she has gone through all neccessary legal steps to end her life. When a woman goes into a clinic to have an abortion, she also complies with the law, but for some reason, there will always be someone who doesn't think she should be allowed the right to do so.
 
 Restaurants are not required to be smoke free. There are some local ordinances that may require it, but it is not a federal law. Workplaces, yes, restaurants, no. Walk into any diner in say, Cheyenne, WY to see it I'm wrong. The reasons a restauranteur might decide to make his establishment non-smoking are numerous. The fact is, in most venues, the smoker is the minority, and so it only makes sense. My own opinion is that, while a smoker can last an hour or so for dinner without dying for a smoke, some vehement non-smokers could not last two minutes if they were within a half mile of a lit cigarette. (you know the type, the suburban soccer mom who coughs on sight of a cigarette, the one who will traipse through a discount motel at midnight looking at 10 rooms because none of them "smell right")

Conception is. Conception is when the fetus has a full DNA; it's own blood type; it's own growth; it's own metabolsim; it's own future.

 
 con·cep·tion ( P ) Pronunciation Key (kn-spshn)
 n. 
 
 Formation of a viable zygote by the union of the male sperm and female ovum; fertilization. 
 The entity formed by the union of the male sperm and female ovum; an embryo or zygote. 
 Archaic. A beginning; a start. 
 
 Ok, so by your reasoning, a fertilized egg is a human. That would include an ectopic pregnancy. In an ectopic, the egg is fertilized, but instead of dropping down to implant in the uterus lining, it adheres to the fallopian tube. In this case, the woman is likely to die if the ectopic is not removed. The problem in this instance is that it is a viable zygote, it is just not in the best environment, so to speak.
 In the case of an abortion, the embryo is also in an undesirable location. it is in the womb of a woman who for whatever reasons would prefer it were not.
 What's the difference? In the first case there is no hope for a healthy pregnancy. the child will not survive. Nature and medicine have decided against it.
 In the second case, there is hope that that child would have a normal life, but it is very uncertain. The parents and the doctor (within the law) have decided against it.
 The way I see it, the first example is the more tragic. Here is a matter medical science has not yet solved, leaving the woman with a painful surgery and emotional distress.
 In the second, I have trust that the people involved made the right choice. Although there will probably be some pain and emotional distress, perhaps it is less than either she or the child would have had in the years to come.

Its a well stated arguement, superbuddhaman. My problem with it is, assuming the unborn at any stage is human, you are then killing that person to prevent them from having a possibly unhappy life. If you can do that, you should also be able to kill any person to prevent an unhappy life. Indeed, it would even make more sense to judge everyone every 10 or so years, and if they are unhappy by some standard, kill them. This makes sense, because you are then only killing people who do, in fact, have unhappy lives. (according to the standard)

 No, I'm talking in medical terms of pregnancy. Lets go back to elementary school math class. A full term pregnancy is 36 weeks. that would be nine months. If you divide that into the three trimesters- that is pretty obvious. so a seventh month pregancy would yes, fall under the third trimester, and be called a late term pregnancy.
 
 Recently here in america they passed a bill into law that makes it illegal for a woman to have a late term abortion, under any circumstances.
 
 This literally will sentence a woman to death in most cases where she would have considered a late term abortion. 
 
 Before this bill, it was extremely difficult for a woman to have this procedure. Basically her doctor had to attest to the fact that her life was being endagered by the pregnancy. 
 
 Ironically, most pro-life people consider a circumstance where the woman's life is in danger to be the only one in which abortion would be acceptable. This decision was strictly for the fanatics and religious right.
 It was most definitely not in the interest of women or their children.

Recently here in america they passed a bill into law that makes it illegal for a woman to have a late term abortion, under any circumstances.

Are you referring to the so-called "Partial Birth Abortion Ban"?

 
 
 Yes I am, fortunately this ban is being challenged in several courts on several levels in several states. I for one am crossing my fingers that the ban is overturned, and the decision goes back to the mother, rather than a bunch of fanatical suits in Washington.

Superbudd, I don't think you know what a partial birth abortion does. It is EXTREMELY painful for the fetus, who at this point looks like a infant! Can you imagine a doctor holding the belly of a fetus and stabbing it in the back of the head causing pain and death to an innocent child? That is SICK.

 I think abortion should be allowed in many circumstances, but I can't name them simply because I (nor anyone else) can not be aware of all possible circumstances.
 
 Suicide.... another delicate subject. I think suicide should be allowed in certain cases, but those are pretty limited. I don't think a 14 year old girl who just got dumped by her first boyfriend should be allowed to do it, but someone who is already dying, whose body is wracked with pain, whose doctors cannot treat that pain for fear of killing them should be able to die.
 I know a man whose father had a severe subdural hemotoma, which left him lying on his kitchen floor for several days before the weekly maid found him there. A few months later he killed himself. He left no note, so we are left to wonder why he did this. Maybe there was another medical event, very common in those cases... maybe he woke up blind, maybe he realized that he was on his way out anyway, and did not want to end up withering in a hospital, using up his children's inheritance on expensive medical treatment that would have only postponed the inevitable. 
 I do think he had every right to end his life.
 I myself have decided that if the time comes when I see my end coming, have serious medical ailments, whatever.... i will end it. But not with a nice overdose or gunshot, I will go up to the mountains and offer myself to bear, return to nature.
 And, I think, that is my choice
Again I ask, why not kill?
